sub_topic: Time dilation in a moving frame of reference
message_1: A spaceship is moving at a speed of 0.6c relative to Earth. Two clocks are on board the ship - one in the cockpit and one in the cargo bay. If the clock in the cockpit shows a time of 3 years when the ship returns to Earth, what will be the time shown on the clock in the cargo bay when it is compared to a clock on Earth? Use the concept of time dilation to calculate the answer.
message_2:
To solve this problem, we need to use the concept of time dilation in special relativity. Time dilation occurs when an object is moving at a significant fraction of the speed of light relative to an observer. In this case, the spaceship is moving at 0.6c relative to Earth.

The time dilation formula is given by:

Δt' = Δt / √(1 - v^2/c^2)

where Δt' is the time experienced by the moving observer (the spaceship), Δt is the time experienced by the stationary observer (Earth), v is the relative velocity between the two observers, and c is the speed of light.

We are given that the clock in the cockpit shows a time of 3 years when the ship returns to Earth. This means that Δt' = 3 years. We are also given that the spaceship is moving at a speed of 0.6c relative to Earth, so v = 0.6c.

Now we can plug these values into the time dilation formula to find the time experienced by the stationary observer (Earth):

Δt = Δt' * √(1 - v^2/c^2)
Δt = 3 years * √(1 - (0.6c)^2/c^2)
Δt = 3 years * √(1 - 0.36)
Δt = 3 years * √(0.64)
Δt = 3 years * 0.8
Δt = 2.4 years

Since both clocks on the spaceship (cockpit and cargo bay) experience the same time dilation, the time shown on the clock in the cargo bay when compared to a clock on Earth will also be 2.4 years.
